intro: Polyalthia chapelieri, commonly known as the Malabar chestnut, is a tropical evergreen tree native to the Western Ghats of India. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its large, leathery leaves and showy, fragrant white flowers. The tree produces small, round fruits that enclose a single seed, which is often used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in dense forest understories. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation areas.
